question: Question_B_06_(d)
statement:
Consider the triangle \emph{T} in three dimensions with vertices
\emph{(0, 1, 2)}, \emph{(1, 1, 5)} and \emph{(â1, 2, 2)}.

Consider also the plane \emph{P} that contains \emph{T}.

Verify that \emph{(0, 0, â1)} is on the plane \emph{P}.
sols:
Plug in \emph{(0, 0, â1)} into the equation in part (c), i.e. put
\emph{x = 0, y = 0, z = -1} into the equation

\[x + y - \frac{1}{3}z = \frac{1}{3}\]

yields $0 + 0 - (-\frac{1}{3}) = \frac{1}{3}$.

Thus \emph{(0, 0, â1)} is on \emph{P}.
